articles.headline: Apple and Google Team Up to ‘Contact Trace’ the Coronavirus
articles.snippet: The technology giants said they would embed a feature in iPhones and Android devices to enable users to track infected people they’d come close to.
articles.abstract: The technology giants said they would embed a feature in iPhones and Android devices to enable users to track infected people they’d come close to.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — In one of the most far-ranging attempts to halt the spread of the coronavirus, Apple and Google said they were building software into smartphones that would tell people if they were recently in contact with someone who was infected with it.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Global Trade Sputters, Leaving Too Much Here, Too Little There
articles.snippet: As the pandemic stretches on, consumers and businesses could run short of some products in months to come.
articles.abstract: As the pandemic stretches on, consumers and businesses could run short of some products in months to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Factories are idled. Workers are in lockdown. Goods are piling up at some ports, while elsewhere container ships sail empty. Dairy farmers are dumping their milk, while toilet paper aisles at the grocery store have been picked bare.

articles.headline: Black-Owned Businesses Could Face Hurdles in Federal Aid Program
articles.snippet: Minority business owners have always struggled to secure bank loans. Now, many banks want to deal only with existing customers when making loans through the government’s $349 billion aid package.
articles.abstract: Minority business owners have always struggled to secure bank loans. Now, many banks want to deal only with existing customers when making loans through the government’s $349 billion aid package.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Yasmine Young walked down the street from Diaspora Salon, the business she owns in Baltimore, to the Bank of America branch where she has a business checking account. She was thinking of getting a credit card, but when a banker there described the requirements she would have to meet to qualify for one, Ms. Young says she left feeling too discouraged to apply.

articles.headline: Torn Over Reopening Economy, Trump Says He Faces ‘Biggest Decision I’ve Ever Had to Make’
articles.snippet: The president suggested he wanted to move soon, but he also promised to listen to public health officials cautioning against relaxing restrictions prematurely.
articles.abstract: The president suggested he wanted to move soon, but he also promised to listen to public health officials cautioning against relaxing restrictions prematurely.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he grapples simultaneously with the most devastating public health and economic crises of a lifetime, President Trump finds himself pulled in opposite directions on what to do next. The bankers, corporate executives and industrialists plead with him to reopen the country as soon as possible, while the medical experts beg for more time to curb the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Biden and Cuomo: Friends, Allies and Supporting Players No Longer
articles.snippet: A personal friendship has grown into a crucial political alliance as the two men have emerged as pillars of the Democratic Party in a national crisis.
articles.abstract: A personal friendship has grown into a crucial political alliance as the two men have emerged as pillars of the Democratic Party in a national crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late July of 2015, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. traversed the state of New York with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, ending the day in Queens, where they announced plans to rebuild La Guardia Airport. On a flight with Mr. Cuomo aboard Air Force Two, Mr. Biden broached a delicate subject: his own interest in the presidency.

articles.headline: ‘You Could Lick the Benches’: Life for the First Wave of U.S. Survivors
articles.snippet: As the rest of the nation shelters in place, the first Americans to recover from the virus test drive immunity.
articles.abstract: As the rest of the nation shelters in place, the first Americans to recover from the virus test drive immunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Christy Karras and her husband received a tantalizing text the other day from friends they had not seen since February, when all four were among the first people in the United States to be sickened by the new coronavirus.

articles.headline: As They Console Coronavirus’s Victims, Italy’s Priests Are Dying, Too
articles.snippet: Doctors and nurses on the front line have become symbols of sacrifice, but priests and nuns have also joined the fight, often at great risk.
articles.abstract: Doctors and nurses on the front line have become symbols of sacrifice, but priests and nuns have also joined the fight, often at great risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — On the Sunday before Easter, the priest’s phone rang.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo

articles.headline: Dumped Milk, Smashed Eggs, Plowed Vegetables: Food Waste of the Pandemic
articles.snippet: With restaurants, hotels and schools closed, many of the nation’s largest farms are destroying millions of pounds of fresh goods that they can no longer sell.
articles.abstract: With restaurants, hotels and schools closed, many of the nation’s largest farms are destroying millions of pounds of fresh goods that they can no longer sell.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Wisconsin and Ohio, farmers are dumping thousands of gallons of fresh milk into lagoons and manure pits. An Idaho farmer has dug huge ditches to bury 1 million pounds of onions. And in South Florida, a region that supplies much of the Eastern half of the United States with produce, tractors are crisscrossing bean and cabbage fields, plowing perfectly ripe vegetables back into the soil.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: He Could Have Seen What Was Coming: Behind Trump’s Failure on the Virus
articles.snippet: An examination reveals the president was warned about the potential for a pandemic but that internal divisions, lack of planning and his faith in his own instincts led to a halting response.
articles.abstract: An examination reveals the president was warned about the potential for a pandemic but that internal divisions, lack of planning and his faith in his own instincts led to a halting response.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, David E. Sanger, Maggie Haberman, Michael D. Shear, Mark Mazzetti and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Oil Nations, Prodded by Trump, Reach Deal to Slash Production
articles.snippet: The deal will reduce output by 9.7 million barrels a day. While significant, the cut falls far short of what is needed to bring oil production in line with demand.
articles.abstract: The deal will reduce output by 9.7 million barrels a day. While significant, the cut falls far short of what is needed to bring oil production in line with demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil-producing nations on Sunday agreed to the largest production cut ever negotiated, in an unprecedented coordinated effort by Russia, Saudi Arabia and the United States to stabilize oil prices and, indirectly, global financial markets.

articles.headline: Flight Attendants and Pilots Ask, ‘Is It OK to Keep Working?’
articles.snippet: The coronavirus has terrified airline crews, yet some are still flying. “I just feel like I’m supposed to be here doing this work,” said one flight attendant.
articles.abstract: The coronavirus has terrified airline crews, yet some are still flying. “I just feel like I’m supposed to be here doing this work,” said one flight attendant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Molly Choma, a flight attendant for Alaska Airlines, had worked nearly every day since mid-March, even as the coronavirus outbreak devastated her industry. But last Sunday, she woke up alone in a room in a nearly empty hotel and wondered if it was time to stop.

articles.headline: Working From Home Feeds Market’s Woes in Little Ways That Add Up
articles.snippet: As traders scattered to their homes, sacrificing fast speeds, multiple screens and intricate setups, decisions took longer to communicate, slowing markets and adding uncertainty.
articles.abstract: As traders scattered to their homes, sacrificing fast speeds, multiple screens and intricate setups, decisions took longer to communicate, slowing markets and adding uncertainty.
articles.lead_paragraph: Toggling between two computer screens instead of four. Slower wireless connections. Plain old cellphones — missed calls and all — standing in for highly programmed devices that allow instantaneous connections. Instant messaging and video conferencing replacing quick bursts of conversation across a floor.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips, Emily Flitter and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: How a Premier U.S. Drug Company Became a Virus ‘Super Spreader’
articles.snippet: Biogen employees unwittingly spread the coronavirus from Massachusetts to Indiana, Tennessee and North Carolina.
articles.abstract: Biogen employees unwittingly spread the coronavirus from Massachusetts to Indiana, Tennessee and North Carolina.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — On the first Monday in March, Michel Vounatsos, chief executive of the drug company Biogen, appeared in good spirits. The company’s new Alzheimer’s drug was showing promise after years of setbacks. Revenues had never been higher.
articles.byline: By Farah Stockman and Kim Barker

articles.headline: ‘There Will Be Losses’: How a Captain’s Plea Exposed a Rift in the Military
articles.snippet: The coronavirus crisis aboard the carrier Theodore Roosevelt spurred another chapter in the hollowing out of the Navy’s leadership, in particular under the Trump administration.
articles.abstract: The coronavirus crisis aboard the carrier Theodore Roosevelt spurred another chapter in the hollowing out of the Navy’s leadership, in particular under the Trump administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The captain had reached a breaking point.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and John Ismay

articles.headline: The Coronavirus Class Divide: Space and Privacy
articles.snippet: “Shelter in place” is a dictate that assumes the existence of shelter — the safe, stable, controlled environment that poor people often lack.
articles.abstract: “Shelter in place” is a dictate that assumes the existence of shelter — the safe, stable, controlled environment that poor people often lack.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are corners of America where social distancing is practiced with care, but the house in Robesonia, Pa., that Mark Stokes shares with 10 other people is not among them.

articles.headline: Bob Iger Thought He Was Leaving on Top. Now, He’s Fighting for Disney’s Life.
articles.snippet: The former C.E.O. thought he was riding into the sunset. Now he’s reasserting control and reimagining Disney as a company with fewer employees and more thermometers.
articles.abstract: The former C.E.O. thought he was riding into the sunset. Now he’s reasserting control and reimagining Disney as a company with fewer employees and more thermometers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Walt Disney Company turned franchises like Marvel and “Star Wars” into the biggest media business in the world, and last fall it was putting the finishing touches on the image of a storied character: its chief executive, Bob Iger.

articles.headline: How Thousands in China Gently Mourn a Coronavirus Whistle-Blower
articles.snippet: Dr. Li Wenliang tried to warn his country but was silenced. Now its traumatized people visit his spirit online.
articles.abstract: Dr. Li Wenliang tried to warn his country but was silenced. Now its traumatized people visit his spirit online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Li Wenliang tried to warn his country but was silenced. Now its traumatized people visit his spirit online.
articles.byline: By Li Yuan and Rumsey Taylor

articles.headline: Big Business Pledged Gentler Capitalism. It’s Not Happening in a Pandemic.
articles.snippet: C.E.O.s who signed a celebrated Business Roundtable document, promising to elevate worker interests, are now resorting to furloughs.
articles.abstract: C.E.O.s who signed a celebrated Business Roundtable document, promising to elevate worker interests, are now resorting to furloughs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last August, the chief executives of 181 of America’s largest corporations signed a document pledging their commitment to run their companies for the benefit of workers and communities, and not just for shareholders.
